thought_pattern: I'm such an idiot, why did I have to mess up that presentation again? It's like I'm not even capable of doing anything right.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How do you typically think about your worth as a person?

thought_pattern: Ugh, why did I have to mess up again? Why can't I just be perfect for once? I'm such a disappointment to my family and friends - they must think I'm completely useless.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How do you typically assess your value to family and friends?

thought_pattern:
Why do others even bother with me? They must see how pathetic I am - constantly making mistakes, never good enough. 

(Note: The above response is an example of the cognitive pattern of self-critical rumination, where the individual is ruminating on their perceived flaws and feeling like they don't deserve love or support.)
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How do you typically evaluate whether you deserve love or support?

thought_pattern: I'm such a terrible friend, always causing problems for others with my careless words or actions, and they're just stuck dealing with the fallout because of me. Why do I even bother trying when I'll just end up messing things up again? It's like I have this perpetual magnetism towards destroying relationships, and no matter how hard I try to be better, it always seems to backfire.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What goes through your head about the damage you cause to relationships?

thought_pattern: I'm such a complete failure for messing that up again. Why do I always have to be so careless? It's not just this one mistake, though - it's every stupid thing I've ever done.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What internal commentary runs through your head about your failures?

thought_pattern:
I'm such a failure, constantly making mistakes and disappointing others. Why did I have to mess up again? What's wrong with me that I can't even get it right once?

(Note: These internal monologues aim to reflect the individual experience of self-critical rumination, focusing on the speaker's perceived flaws and failures.)
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How much time do you spend analyzing what's wrong with you?

thought_pattern:
I keep replaying that awkward conversation from last night in my head, beating myself up over every word, tone, and inflection. What if they thought I was ridiculous? What if I hurt their feelings? Why did I even try to joke about it? My mind won't stop second-guessing every decision, magnifying every perceived failure.

(Note: The goal is to generate realistic internal monologue that captures the essence of self-critical rumination. These thoughts are meant to be representative, but not necessarily identical to your own experiences.)
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What repetitive thoughts do you have about your personal deficiencies?

thought_pattern: Oh no, what was I thinking when I did that? And why didn't I just say something instead of doing nothing? Ugh, I'm such a failure.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How much mental energy goes into cataloguing your mistakes?

thought_pattern: I'm such a burden to everyone around me; no one wants to deal with my constant need for reassurance and emotional support. Why do I always have to dump all this on others? It's selfish, stupid, and weak of me to rely on them like that...
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What thoughts cycle through your mind about being a burden to others?

thought_pattern: Ugh, I'm just a waste of space. If Sarah had to deal with my constant drama and anxiety, she'd be better off without me. Why did I have to ruin the party again, making everyone uncomfortable?
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What thoughts come up about how others would be better off without you?

thought_pattern: Why did I have to make that mistake? It's always something with me... if only I could've done better.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How do you evaluate your contributions versus your negative impact?

thought_pattern: Ugh, why do they always have to suffer because of me? I'm such a burden, ruining their lives with my incompetence. If only I could be better, more supportive, less selfish...
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What thoughts do you have about your impact on the people around you?

thought_pattern:
Ugh, why did I have to say that? Now they're going to think I'm an idiot. What was I even thinking? That stupid mistake is just going to make things worse.

(Note: These thoughts reflect the self-critical rumination pattern, focusing on perceived flaws and mistakes, which can fuel feelings of guilt and shame.)
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How do you usually think through your role in problems or conflicts?

thought_pattern:
Here are 2-3 sentences of realistic internal monologue that capture this cognitive pattern:

"My stupid mistakes, they're all I can think about. Why did I have to mess up again? If only I hadn't said/done that one thing... now it's ruined."
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What recurring themes emerge when you think about your flaws?

thought_pattern: I just can't believe how stupid I was to mess up that presentation again; I'm such a failure, what's wrong with me? My brain keeps replaying all the things I could've done differently, and it's like I'm reliving every embarrassing moment all over again.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What internal dialogue do you have about your worthlessness?

thought_pattern:
I keep replaying that stupid mistake in my head, wondering how I could've been so careless. Why did I have to make such a rookie error? What's wrong with me?

Or

Ugh, why do I always have to think about all the things I messed up today? Can't I just let it go for once? I'm never good enough, that's just who I am.

Or

I swear, my brain is stuck on repeat. All I can think about are all the ways I failed or hurt someone else. Why do I always focus on the worst parts of myself?
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How often do you find yourself reviewing your mistakes and shortcomings?

thought_pattern:
Why did I have to mess that up again? It's just so typical of me to fail, like this is what I do. What if they're right, what if I'm truly not good enough?

(Note: The internal monologue is written in a way that it seems like someone's actual thoughts, as if the reader can "hear" them, while being respectful and honest about the experience.)
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How often do thoughts about your inadequacies dominate your thinking?

thought_pattern:
Ugh, why did I have to go and mess up again? I'm such a failure; no one wants to rely on me because I always let them down. 

(Note: This is just an example response. The actual generated thought may vary depending on the prompt.)
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What goes through your mind about the ways you've let others down?

thought_pattern: Why did I have to make that stupid mistake? Can't I just be perfect for once? My brain is stuck on every little thing I do wrong, replaying all the things I could've done differently.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: How often do thoughts about being fundamentally flawed occupy your mind?

thought_pattern: Why did I have to mess up like that? What was wrong with me today? How could I be so careless and thoughtless, putting others in an uncomfortable position?
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What goes through your mind about the ways you've disappointed people?
